full_translation:
**The Supreme Clarity Scripture of the Golden Casket and Jade Mirror: Esoteric Instructions on Cultivating the True and Mysterious**

**Scripture Title:** *The Supreme Clarity Scripture of the Golden Casket and Jade Mirror: Esoteric Instructions on Cultivating the True and Mysterious*. Author unknown, approximately composed during the Sui or Tang dynasties. It expounds upon the methods of venerating the Heavenly Worthy to deliver the deceased and dispel calamities. One scroll.

**Source of Base Text:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Dongxuan* Section, *Benwen* Category.

---

The Supreme Dao Lord, seated amidst the Purple Empyrean Grove within the Jade Void Grotto of Supreme Clarity, was joined by the assembled immortals of the heavens and the perfected officials of the three realms. There, he proclaimed this *True Scripture of Esoteric Instructions on Cultivating the True and Mysterious*, addressing the immortal assembly:

"Beings below in the mortal realm, ignorant of the true Dao, commit manifold transgressions, sinking into boundless suffering. Those who accumulate sins know not how to cleanse them, while those who cultivate and nurture wholly deviate from the true Dao. Thus, the paths of evil overflow, and the gates of life vanish without trace.

I now reveal to you these essential teachings, directly dissecting the profound purport of the Primordial Origin, to transmit them to the faithful and sincere. Through cultivating the body and preserving life, one may pacify the state and secure the household. When merit is fulfilled and deeds perfected, the body transcends the three realms, ancestors are delivered, and descendants are blessed with prosperity. This sacred and numinous text—attend to it with utmost reverence."

The Dao Lord spoke:
"Heaven and earth are bound and constricted, yet the myriad things transform and harmonize. Inheriting their karmic conditions, they converge through the workings of causes and conditions. When father and mother unite, the person receives life. The fetus complete and qi replete, the spirit descends into the void. The Great One resides in the brain, presiding over the Mud Pill Palace. The Controller of Destiny abides in the heart, receiving the source of life. On the left dwells the Non-Flourishing, on the right coalesces the White Prime. The Three Perfected and Nine Palaces are arrayed in full. The liver houses the ethereal soul, the lungs the corporeal soul; the spleen, the will; the kidneys, the essence. The heart governs the spirit, the Cinnabar Prime guards the numinous. Modeling heaven and emulating earth, bearing yin and embracing yang, the five phases intermingle in correspondence with the four seasons. The eyes are the sun and moon, the hair the stars. The brows are named the Florid Canopy, the head is Mount Kunlun. Each has its palaces and chambers, where the spirit is settled. Among the myriad things, none are more noble or numinous.

Life arises from the Dao, nature is endowed by the One. At the moment of birth, the spirit is pure and quiescent. Yet as the uncarved block scatters, it pursues delusion and depletes the true. Impurity, stench, and filth disorder the form and spirit. In tranquil observation, what is distant and what is near? Guard the Dao and preserve life, do good and safeguard the true. The foolish are enslaved by things, vainly enduring hardship and toil.

I disseminate the true teaching solely to exhort the worthy and the wise. Diligently seek its purport, refining and tempering day and night. By eliminating transgressions and defilements, one may prolong life. Above, transcend the three realms; below, deliver the shades of the underworld. Recite, uphold, venerate, and contemplate without regress. When merit is accomplished and deeds perfected, one shall surely attain immortality."

The Dao declared:
"The heart governs the form, dwelling place of the spirit. Qi, fluids, blood, and essence—when the heart is at peace, they are naturally regulated. Its governance is unperturbed, its people are pure; its governance is scrutinizing, its people are deficient.

The way of nurturing the heart lies in caution regarding busyness. Arrogance must not be indulged, desires must not be followed, ambitions must not be fulfilled, and pleasures must not be pursued to excess. No sin is greater than indulging desire, no misfortune greater than insatiability. If one can be content with one’s lot and curb greed, empty the heart and dispel desires, then the true source will become serene, and the numinous radiance will naturally shine. Without thought, without action, one gradually harmonizes with the true Dao."

The Dao declared:
"Qi is borne by form, form is filled by qi. When form is complete, qi lingers; when qi is harmonious, form is preserved. Heaven and earth take clarity and turbidity as their substance; without qi, they cannot circulate yin and yang. The sun and moon are distinguished by brightness and darkness; without qi, they cannot unite the ethereal and corporeal souls. Among plants, all wither and decay, yet only the pine and cypress remain evergreen—such is the firmness of their qi. Fish perish in drought, yet only the tortoise and crane remain unwearied—such is the abiding of their qi.

Form is the dwelling that retains qi, qi is the tally that preserves form. To retain form and abide in the world, one must first cultivate qi. Vast and unyielding, it fills the space between heaven and earth. When qi gathers, it becomes numinous, roaming beyond the dust and wind. Thus, qi resides within the person, and the person resides within qi. The myriad things of heaven and earth are all born of qi.

Those who skillfully cultivate qi nurture the body within and repel evil without, though the common people use it daily without awareness. Those who know and cultivate it, silently perfecting it, may stave off hunger and cold, ward off pestilence and plague. Venomous creatures and toxic things—qi can restrain them. Of the myriad methods and thousand defenses, qi is the origin.

The way of cultivating qi lies in being cautious in speech and moderate in diet, curbing anger and restraining desires. Seal the orifices, close the gates, maintain it subtly as if present, using it without exhaustion.

The way of nurturing form lies in blunting sharpness and harmonizing brilliance, governing before disorder arises. Be at ease without toil, toil without exhausting strength, be tranquil without disturbance, disturbed without disordering qi. Externally, there is supplementation; internally, there is benefit. In nurturing form and preserving qi, all is thus prepared."

The Dao declared:
"When form and qi are both established, one must safeguard the spirit. The mechanism of creation and transformation lies herein. When essence is whole, the spirit flourishes; when essence is depleted, the spirit wanes. Through essence, the spirit is gathered and preserved; through the spirit, the form is employed and at peace.

The kidneys are the palace of essence; overuse leads to exhaustion—concentration and conservation are fitting. The heart is the abode of the spirit; overuse leads to fatigue—quiescence and nurturance are fitting. Only through quiescence and concentration can one inwardly guard.

Thus it is said: The true essence of the supreme Dao is profound and obscure; the ultimate of the supreme Dao is dim and silent. Without seeing, without hearing, embrace the spirit in stillness. The form will naturally rectify. Be still, be pure, do not labor your form, do not agitate your essence. Reduce selfishness, diminish desires—only then can one attain long life."

The Dao declared:
"The method is fundamentally without method; its principle returns to spontaneity. The heart is disturbed by circumstances; the method arises from the heart. The intent of establishing methods is to remedy what has been lost and prevent what has yet to arise.

If one violates and damages the Three Marvels, first repair and treat them. Only when repair is complete may one advance in merit. To advance without completion is labor in vain."

The methods of repair and treatment are expounded in their profundity by the Primordial Unity; the prescriptions for measuring merit are fully revealed in their subtlety by the Numinous Treasure. When prior merits manifest verification, one may advance to the next stage of practice. When merit is fulfilled and perfection attained, one ascends or descends according to one’s conduct. Merit without conduct invites demonic obstacles and hinders attainment; conduct sustained by merit naturally elevates one to the ranks of immortals. When virtuous merit reaches completion, auspicious blessings descend.

Cultivation of nature and practice of conduct must clarify distinctions of rank. Those who seek to become Heavenly Immortals must establish one thousand three hundred good deeds; those who seek to become Earthly Immortals must establish three hundred good deeds. Follow the Dao and advance; depart from it and retreat. Do not tread the path of depravity, nor deceive in the secrecy of darkness. Accumulate deeds and amass merit, extend compassion to all beings, uphold loyalty and filial piety, foster harmony among kin, rectify oneself to transform others, show mercy to orphans and succor widows, respect the elderly and cherish the young. Even insects and plants must not be harmed. Such is the so-called virtuous person: all people revere them, the Dao of Heaven protects them, blessings and prosperity follow them, all evil departs from them, their undertakings invariably succeed, and the attainment of immortality may be hoped for.

The Dao declared:
"Those who wish to cultivate the Dao must first cease and eliminate. Ceasing means that not a single thing arises; eliminating means that all entanglements are stilled. Only then may one gather the spirit in the sea of qi, store breath in the cinnabar field, perfect one’s nature and preserve the true, abiding in profound tranquility. Through such practice over time, one will naturally attain mastery."

The Primordial Heavenly Worthy sat in serene quiescence upon the Seat of Empty Mystery, and the thirty-six thousand spirits all paid homage within the Jeweled Pearl. Thus, the two luminaries merge qi, and spirit commingles in the Cauldron of Ten Flowers. Male and female incline their hearts, uniting essence in the Furnace of Five Qi. Through refining essence, transforming sound, and altering breath, inhaling and exhaling at the Gate of Mystery, concentrating qi and embracing spirit, refining in the vessels of yin and yang, one naturally reverses white hair to black, regrows fallen teeth, restores youth and returns to infancy, attains longevity and enduring vision, preserves life and protects vitality, thereby uniting with the Dao. One shall then share the same durability as Heaven and Earth, and partake in their eternal endurance.

The Dao declared:
"Those who study the Dao establish virtue and merit, refine qi and sit in forgetfulness, cultivate the true and ingest the numinous, expound scriptures and propagate teachings, assist the state and deliver people—all such practices constitute their vocation. Though merit and conduct may be complete and the fruition of practice perfect, one must first deliver the nine generations of ancestors and the seven lineages of parents, liberating their departed spirits, ascending them to Heaven, and erasing their names from the ghostly registers. Only then may one’s own body attain the Dao.

Moreover, in this world of mundane customs, people commit evil and accumulate transgressions, bringing calamity upon their ancestors. Out of compassion, I now proclaim these essential words to deliver and uplift the souls of the departed, which must rely upon meritorious deeds. One may place an image of the deceased, dressed in robes, beside the statues of the Three Clarities, and inscribe the Nine True Wondrous Seals according to the proper method, allowing the departed to carry them in a scroll. Then, perform the repentance ritual of this scripture, three times daily. If unable to perform the repentance, recite with sincere intent the name of the Heavenly Worthy Who Saves from Suffering by Responding to Sounds three thousand times each day. After every hundred recitations, bow nine times and pray: *May the soul of so-and-so swiftly depart the dark yin realms and ascend to the celestial realms.* Those with lighter offenses will be delivered in three days; those with heavier offenses will ascend in nine days. Filial sons and daughters should urgently and sincerely perform this with utmost devotion, reverently paying homage to the sages.

With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of the Void and Spontaneity.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Jade Dawn Lord of the Great Dao.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Supreme Sage Ancestor Lord Lao.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy Who Inclines the Heart to the Dao.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy of Pure Thought and Cultivation.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy Who Repents and Erases Evil Traces.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy Who Delivers from Sin and Obstacles.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy Who Rescues and Dissolves Obstacles.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy Who Saves the Dark Realms.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy Who Extinguishes the Wheel of Suffering.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy Who Delivers the Nine Dark Realms.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy Who Ascends the Five Paths.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the True Person of Great Compassion and Great Mercy Who Saves from Suffering.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the True Person of Great Compassion, Great Mercy, and Great Kindness.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the True Person of Great Compassion and Great Mercy Who Delivers from Sin.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the True Person of Great Compassion, Great Mercy, and Universal Salvation."

Upon completing the homage, express repentance with utmost sincerity:
"Your disciple, so-and-so, reflecting upon my foolish sojourn in the human realm, have fortunately encountered the true transformation. I am grateful for the grace of Heaven and Earth’s sheltering and bearing, and the virtue of the sun and moon’s illumination. Moreover, I contemplate the roots of my parents and ancestors, their birth, nurturing, and upbringing, and recall the greatness of their toil. Truly, I should repay them with deliverance. Now, before the sagely perfected, I pour out my heart in earnest supplication, praying that the countless generations of my ancestors and all departed spirits may have their transgressions accumulated over kalpas fully absolved, that their present sufferings in the realms of darkness may be wholly alleviated, that their karmic entanglements be instantly released, that they ascend by following the light of wisdom, swiftly attain the celestial shore, receive the celestial mandate to pay homage to the perfected, forever escape the cycle of rebirth, and together dwell in eternal bliss. May the qi of Heaven return to their bodies, and may they always enjoy the protection of the Dao. Your disciple is utterly overwhelmed by sorrowful sincerity and earnest supplication."

The Dao declared:
"Devout men and women who offer prayers for the departed and blessings for the living, who seek fortune and avert calamity, must conduct themselves with utmost reverence and care. Bathe in fragrant water, purify body and mind, focus the intent and pour out the heart, reverently recite the true scriptures, and extol the sacred names. With perfect sincerity, one will surely attain spiritual resonance, deliver the living and the dead, dispel misfortune, and bring blessings. If one is irreverent or careless, deluded in nature or doubtful in heart, or if one approaches the scriptures with the stench of meat, alcohol, or lust, one defiles the sacred texts with idle chatter and lip service, laboring in vain and instead inviting calamity. Thus, cultivating blessings is not as effective as avoiding transgressions.

If one copies and distributes this scripture, disseminating it among learners and transmitting it for recitation, the souls of the departed will be delivered, the hells will be pacified, and the blessings accumulated will extend to future generations. Those who possess treasured adornments, clothing, or wealth should broadly bestow them upon the destitute and relieve the impoverished. Such meritorious deeds are comparable to the aforementioned practices: names are erased from the black registers, records are expunged from the Earth Bureau, spirits ascend to contend for the sacred land, and one is reborn according to their wishes, bringing benefit to descendants and severing misfortune and afflictions. The magnitude of such blessings and virtues is beyond measure."

Therefore, one ought to diligently and attentively receive, proclaim, perform rites, and recite, universally delivering boundless beings. In accordance with the teachings, one should uphold them and, moreover, pay reverence to all Heavenly Worthies.

With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Primordial Heavenly Worthy of the Void and Spontaneous Dao
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Supreme Jade Dawn Dao Lord of the Great Dao
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Supreme Mysterious Origin Sage Ancestor Lord Lao
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy Who Constantly and Kindly Saves All Beings
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy of Limitless Salvation
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy Who Delivers the Deluded and Dispels Obstructions
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy of Mysterious Transformation and Beneficent Life
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy of the Golden Portal Who Rescues and Delivers
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Unobstructed and Free Heavenly Worthy
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy Who Pities Life and Benefits All Beings
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy of Vast Merit and Vast Salvation
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy Who Showers Treasures to Relieve the Needy
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy of Boundless Deliverance
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy Who Cherishes Beings and Saves the World
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy of Primordial and Measureless Merit
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy Who Revives the Dead and Raises the Bones
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy Who Refines the Body and Ascends to Perfection
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy Who Expounds the Mysterious Origin and Propagates the Teachings
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy of Virtue and the Dao Who Delivers All Beings
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Heavenly Worthy Who Dispels Disasters and Prolongs Life
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Perfected One Who Pardons and Blesses, Extending Life
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Perfected One of True Stillness and Perfect Merit
With sincere devotion, pay reverence to:
The Perfected One Who Cultivates the True and Attains the Dao

Upon the conclusion of the rites, with utmost sincerity and reverence, I, your disciple [Name], prostrate myself in prayer and gratitude:

I have heard that within the fulfillment of conduct, filial piety and reverence come first; within the teachings and precepts, the practice of purification rites is fundamental. To repay the boundless virtue of my loving parents, one must ponder the methods of prayer and invocation. To requite their infinite kindness, I now present these solemn offerings.

In this world of mortals, all are driven by the pursuit of fame and profit. Once entangled in schemes of gain and loss, how can one avoid the faults of greed and delusion? Thus, life departs in a single breath, and the soul is consigned to the Nine Dark Realms. Relying upon the causes of supreme goodness, may the suffering of the drowned and submerged be uplifted. With a heart full of sorrowful entreaty, I dedicate this merit to my departed ancestors.

Reciting the sacred scriptures from the Golden Casket, I look up to implore the True Sages. Honoring the exalted titles of the Lofty and Void, I bow to repay the roots of my lineage. I humbly pray that by the power of this Dao, the drowned and sunken may be broadly delivered; that measureless transgressions be extinguished, and the long night be illuminated; that the great pardon of Heaven be bestowed, universally benefiting all beings. May the myriad generations of my ancestors, from the most distant to the nearest, all attain the ascent to transcendence. May accumulated debts and layered grievances all be granted liberation and deliverance.

Furthermore, I pray that my household—young and old, kin and relations—may constantly partake in auspicious blessings and receive the sheltering shade of the Void and Nonexistence.

I, your servant, gaze toward Heaven and long for the Sages, overwhelmed with fervent devotion.

The Dao declares: The mysterious scriptures have now fully circulated. They may be transmitted to the world to broadly extend salvation and deliverance.

At that time, the assembled multitude, upon hearing this Dharma-condition, penetrated the Unconditioned. Together, they ascended to the fruition of the Dao. In the Fengdu prisons of the netherworld, countless sinful souls all attained meritorious transformation and were instantly liberated. The hosts of Heavenly Immortals rejoiced, paid reverence, and withdrew.

Here ends *The Wondrous Scripture of the Golden Casket and Jade Mirror: Pointers to the Mysteries of Cultivating the True*.

chunks.original_text: 上清金匮玉镜修真指玄妙经 经名：上清金匮玉镜修真指玄妙经。 撰人不详，约出於隋唐。 言礼拜天尊度亡消灾之法。 一卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞玄部本文类。 上清金匮玉镜修真指玄妙经 太上道君於上清玉虚洞紫霄林中，与诸天仙众三界真官俱在会坐，说此修真指玄真经，告仙众曰：下方众生，不知正道，作诸罪障，沉没无边，造罪者不知洗涤，修养者全乖正道，是致恶道盈涂，生门绝迹。 吾今为汝宣说要言，直剖玄元之旨，付传清信之流，修身保命，安国宁家，行满功成，身超三界，升拔根祖，庆延子孙，秘典灵章，宜加谛听。 道君曰：天地捆缢，万物化醇。 承其宿业，因缘运会。 父母和合，人受其生。 胎完炁足，虚中降神。 太一居脑，以镇泥丸。 司命处心，以纳生源。 左居无英，右结白元。 三真九宫，布列俱全。 肝魂肺魄，脾志肾精。 心主藏神，丹元守灵。 法天象地，负阴抱阳。 分错五行，以应四时。 眼为日月，发为星辰。 眉号华盖，头即昆仑。 各有宫阙，安置精神。 万物之中，最贵而灵。 命生於道，性禀於一。 物生之时，神乎清静。 洎乎朴散，逐妄耗真。 不净臭秽，浊乱形神。 静观物我，何疏何亲。 守道全生，为善保真。 愚役於物，徒自苦辛。 吾敷正教，惟勖贤英。 勤寻旨趣，日炼时烹。 能除罪垢，可以延龄。 上超三界，下拔幽冥。 诵持礼念，无退前程。 功成行就，必证长生。 道言：心为形主，神所居焉。 炁液血精，心安自治。 其政闷闷，其民淳淳，其政察察，其民缺缺。 养心之道，慎于多事，傲不可长，欲不可从，志不可满，乐不可极，罪莫大於可欲，祸莫大於不知足。 若能安分止贪，虚心遣欲，则真源湛然，灵光自莹，无思无为，渐合真道矣。 道言：炁以形载，形以炁充，形完则炁留，炁和则形保。 天地以清浊为质，非炁不足以运阴阳，日月以明暗分形，非炁不足以交魂魄。 众植雕残，独松 柏之常茂者，炁坚也鱼，旱动灭寂，惟龟鹤之不悴者，炁住也。 形为留炁之舍，炁是保形之符，欲留形住世，必先养炁，至大至刚，充塞乎天地之间，炁聚炁灵，遨游乎风尘之外。 故知炁在人中，人在炁中，天地万物莫不由炁以生者也。 善养炁者，内以养身，外以却恶，百姓日用而不知焉。 知之修炼，默而成之，可救饥寒，可辟邪疠，恶虫毒物，炁能禁之，万法千卫，惟炁是祖。 养炁之道，要在慎言节食，惩忿窒欲，塞其兑，闭其门，绵绵若存，用之不勤。 养形之道，要在挫锐和光，治於未乱，安而不劳，劳而不乏其力，静而不挠，挠而不乱其炁。 外有所补，内有所益，养形保炁，於斯备矣。 道言：形炁具立，当保精神，造化之机，在於是矣。 然精全则神王，精耗则神衰，以精集神而神保，以神使形而形安。 肾为精府，太用则竭，专而啬之可也，心为神舍，太用则劳，静而养之可也，惟静与专，然可内守。 故曰：至道之真，杳杳冥冥，至道之极，昏昏默默，无视无听，抱神以静，形将自正，必静必清，无劳汝形，无摇汝精，少私寡欲，乃可长生。 道言：法本无法，理归自然，心因境乱，法本心生，立法之意，救补已失而防於未萌。 若人犯破三奇，即先补治，补之完备，然可进功，不完而进，徒劳无益。

Impurity, stench, and filth disorder the form and spirit. In tranquil observation, what is distant and what is near? Guard the Dao and preserve life, do good and safeguard the true. The foolish are enslaved by things, vainly enduring hardship and toil.

I disseminate the true teaching solely to exhort the worthy and the wise. Diligently seek its purport, refining and tempering day and night. By eliminating transgressions and defilements, one may prolong life. Above, transcend the three realms; below, deliver the shades of the underworld. Recite, uphold, venerate, and contemplate without regress. When merit is accomplished and deeds perfected, one shall surely attain immortality."

The Dao declared:
"The heart governs the form, dwelling place of the spirit. Qi, fluids, blood, and essence—when the heart is at peace, they are naturally regulated. Its governance is unperturbed, its people are pure; its governance is scrutinizing, its people are deficient.

The way of nurturing the heart lies in caution regarding busyness. Arrogance must not be indulged, desires must not be followed, ambitions must not be fulfilled, and pleasures must not be pursued to excess. No sin is greater than indulging desire, no misfortune greater than insatiability. If one can be content with one’s lot and curb greed, empty the heart and dispel desires, then the true source will become serene, and the numinous radiance will naturally shine. Without thought, without action, one gradually harmonizes with the true Dao."

The Dao declared:
"Qi is borne by form, form is filled by qi. When form is complete, qi lingers; when qi is harmonious, form is preserved. Heaven and earth take clarity and turbidity as their substance; without qi, they cannot circulate yin and yang. The sun and moon are distinguished by brightness and darkness; without qi, they cannot unite the ethereal and corporeal souls. Among plants, all wither and decay, yet only the pine and cypress remain evergreen—such is the firmness of their qi. Fish perish in drought, yet only the tortoise and crane remain unwearied—such is the abiding of their qi.

Form is the dwelling that retains qi, qi is the tally that preserves form. To retain form and abide in the world, one must first cultivate qi. Vast and unyielding, it fills the space between heaven and earth. When qi gathers, it becomes numinous, roaming beyond the dust and wind. Thus, qi resides within the person, and the person resides within qi. The myriad things of heaven and earth are all born of qi.

Those who skillfully cultivate qi nurture the body within and repel evil without, though the common people use it daily without awareness. Those who know and cultivate it, silently perfecting it, may stave off hunger and cold, ward off pestilence and plague. Venomous creatures and toxic things—qi can restrain them. Of the myriad methods and thousand defenses, qi is the origin.

The way of cultivating qi lies in being cautious in speech and moderate in diet, curbing anger and restraining desires. Seal the orifices, close the gates, maintain it subtly as if present, using it without exhaustion.

The way of nurturing form lies in blunting sharpness and harmonizing brilliance, governing before disorder arises. Be at ease without toil, toil without exhausting strength, be tranquil without disturbance, disturbed without disordering qi. Externally, there is supplementation; internally, there is benefit. In nurturing form and preserving qi, all is thus prepared."

The Dao declared:
"When form and qi are both established, one must safeguard the spirit. The mechanism of creation and transformation lies herein. When essence is whole, the spirit flourishes; when essence is depleted, the spirit wanes. Through essence, the spirit is gathered and preserved; through the spirit, the form is employed and at peace.

The kidneys are the palace of essence; overuse leads to exhaustion—concentration and conservation are fitting. The heart is the abode of the spirit; overuse leads to fatigue—quiescence and nurturance are fitting. Only through quiescence and concentration can one inwardly guard.

Thus it is said: The true essence of the supreme Dao is profound and obscure; the ultimate of the supreme Dao is dim and silent. Without seeing, without hearing, embrace the spirit in stillness. The form will naturally rectify. Be still, be pure, do not labor your form, do not agitate your essence. Reduce selfishness, diminish desires—only then can one attain long life."

The Dao declared:
"The method is fundamentally without method; its principle returns to spontaneity. The heart is disturbed by circumstances; the method arises from the heart. The intent of establishing methods is to remedy what has been lost and prevent what has yet to arise.

If one violates and damages the Three Marvels, first repair and treat them. Only when repair is complete may one advance in merit. To advance without completion is labor in vain."

chunks.translated_text:
The methods of repair and treatment are expounded in their profundity by the Primordial Unity; the prescriptions for measuring merit are fully revealed in their subtlety by the Numinous Treasure. When prior merits manifest verification, one may advance to the next stage of practice. When merit is fulfilled and perfection attained, one ascends or descends according to one’s conduct. Merit without conduct invites demonic obstacles and hinders attainment; conduct sustained by merit naturally elevates one to the ranks of immortals. When virtuous merit reaches completion, auspicious blessings descend.

Cultivation of nature and practice of conduct must clarify distinctions of rank. Those who seek to become Heavenly Immortals must establish one thousand three hundred good deeds; those who seek to become Earthly Immortals must establish three hundred good deeds. Follow the Dao and advance; depart from it and retreat. Do not tread the path of depravity, nor deceive in the secrecy of darkness. Accumulate deeds and amass merit, extend compassion to all beings, uphold loyalty and filial piety, foster harmony among kin, rectify oneself to transform others, show mercy to orphans and succor widows, respect the elderly and cherish the young. Even insects and plants must not be harmed. Such is the so-called virtuous person: all people revere them, the Dao of Heaven protects them, blessings and prosperity follow them, all evil departs from them, their undertakings invariably succeed, and the attainment of immortality may be hoped for.

The Dao declared:
"Those who wish to cultivate the Dao must first cease and eliminate. Ceasing means that not a single thing arises; eliminating means that all entanglements are stilled. Only then may one gather the spirit in the sea of qi, store breath in the cinnabar field, perfect one’s nature and preserve the true, abiding in profound tranquility. Through such practice over time, one will naturally attain mastery."

The Primordial Heavenly Worthy sat in serene quiescence upon the Seat of Empty Mystery, and the thirty-six thousand spirits all paid homage within the Jeweled Pearl. Thus, the two luminaries merge qi, and spirit commingles in the Cauldron of Ten Flowers. Male and female incline their hearts, uniting essence in the Furnace of Five Qi. Through refining essence, transforming sound, and altering breath, inhaling and exhaling at the Gate of Mystery, concentrating qi and embracing spirit, refining in the vessels of yin and yang, one naturally reverses white hair to black, regrows fallen teeth, restores youth and returns to infancy, attains longevity and enduring vision, preserves life and protects vitality, thereby uniting with the Dao. One shall then share the same durability as Heaven and Earth, and partake in their eternal endurance.

The Dao declared:
"Those who study the Dao establish virtue and merit, refine qi and sit in forgetfulness, cultivate the true and ingest the numinous, expound scriptures and propagate teachings, assist the state and deliver people—all such practices constitute their vocation. Though merit and conduct may be complete and the fruition of practice perfect, one must first deliver the nine generations of ancestors and the seven lineages of parents, liberating their departed spirits, ascending them to Heaven, and erasing their names from the ghostly registers. Only then may one’s own body attain the Dao.

Moreover, in this world of mundane customs, people commit evil and accumulate transgressions, bringing calamity upon their ancestors. Out of compassion, I now proclaim these essential words to deliver and uplift the souls of the departed, which must rely upon meritorious deeds. One may place an image of the deceased, dressed in robes, beside the statues of the Three Clarities, and inscribe the Nine True Wondrous Seals according to the proper method, allowing the departed to carry them in a scroll. Then, perform the repentance ritual of this scripture, three times daily. If unable to perform the repentance, recite with sincere intent the name of the Heavenly Worthy Who Saves from Suffering by Responding to Sounds three thousand times each day. After every hundred recitations, bow nine times and pray: *May the soul of so-and-so swiftly depart the dark yin realms and ascend to the celestial realms.* Those with lighter offenses will be delivered in three days; those with heavier offenses will ascend in nine days. Filial sons and daughters should urgently and sincerely perform this with utmost devotion, reverently paying homage to the sages.

With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of the Void and Spontaneity.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Jade Dawn Lord of the Great Dao.
With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the Supreme Sage Ancestor Lord Lao.

With sincere intent, reverently pay homage to the True Person of Great Compassion, Great Mercy, and Universal Salvation."

Upon completing the homage, express repentance with utmost sincerity:
"Your disciple, so-and-so, reflecting upon my foolish sojourn in the human realm, have fortunately encountered the true transformation. I am grateful for the grace of Heaven and Earth’s sheltering and bearing, and the virtue of the sun and moon’s illumination. Moreover, I contemplate the roots of my parents and ancestors, their birth, nurturing, and upbringing, and recall the greatness of their toil. Truly, I should repay them with deliverance. Now, before the sagely perfected, I pour out my heart in earnest supplication, praying that the countless generations of my ancestors and all departed spirits may have their transgressions accumulated over kalpas fully absolved, that their present sufferings in the realms of darkness may be wholly alleviated, that their karmic entanglements be instantly released, that they ascend by following the light of wisdom, swiftly attain the celestial shore, receive the celestial mandate to pay homage to the perfected, forever escape the cycle of rebirth, and together dwell in eternal bliss. May the qi of Heaven return to their bodies, and may they always enjoy the protection of the Dao. Your disciple is utterly overwhelmed by sorrowful sincerity and earnest supplication."

The Dao declared:
"Devout men and women who offer prayers for the departed and blessings for the living, who seek fortune and avert calamity, must conduct themselves with utmost reverence and care. Bathe in fragrant water, purify body and mind, focus the intent and pour out the heart, reverently recite the true scriptures, and extol the sacred names. With perfect sincerity, one will surely attain spiritual resonance, deliver the living and the dead, dispel misfortune, and bring blessings. If one is irreverent or careless, deluded in nature or doubtful in heart, or if one approaches the scriptures with the stench of meat, alcohol, or lust, one defiles the sacred texts with idle chatter and lip service, laboring in vain and instead inviting calamity. Thus, cultivating blessings is not as effective as avoiding transgressions.

If one copies and distributes this scripture, disseminating it among learners and transmitting it for recitation, the souls of the departed will be delivered, the hells will be pacified, and the blessings accumulated will extend to future generations. Those who possess treasured adornments, clothing, or wealth should broadly bestow them upon the destitute and relieve the impoverished. Such meritorious deeds are comparable to the aforementioned practices: names are erased from the black registers, records are expunged from the Earth Bureau, spirits ascend to contend for the sacred land, and one is reborn according to their wishes, bringing benefit to descendants and severing misfortune and afflictions. The magnitude of such blessings and virtues is beyond measure."

chunks.original_text: 礼竟，恢诚恭伸梼谢：弟子臣某甲伏闻行成之内，孝敬为先，教法之中，修斋是本，欲报慈亲之德，须思梼祝之方，将酬罔极之恩，是列严持之供。 大凡人世，俱逼名利为端，既怀取舍之谋，宁免贪痴之咎，致使命辞一世，魂寄九幽，敢凭上善之因，庶拔漂沉之苦，是则心存哀恳，志荐先亡。 宣金匮之灵章，仰祈真圣，礼高虚之御号，俯答根宗。 伏愿承斯道力，广济沉沦，灭无量之罪尤，均开长夜，赐大天之鸿宥，普及群生，亿曾万祖，俱获遂於飞升，积债叠冤，并乞蒙於超适，然冀居家长幼，眷属亲姻，常沾吉庆之祈，求荷虚无之荫。 臣元任瞻天望圣，激切屏营之至。 道言：玄经周毕，可以传教世间，广垂济度。 尔时会众闻此法缘，洞达无为，齐升道果，酆幽诸狱，无量罪魂，俱获善功，应时解脱，诸天仙众，欢喜敬奉，作礼而退。 上清金匮玉镜修真指玄妙经竟
chunks.translated_text:
Upon the conclusion of the rites, with utmost sincerity and reverence, I, your disciple [Name], prostrate myself in prayer and gratitude:

I have heard that within the fulfillment of conduct, filial piety and reverence come first; within the teachings and precepts, the practice of purification rites is fundamental. To repay the boundless virtue of my loving parents, one must ponder the methods of prayer and invocation. To requite their infinite kindness, I now present these solemn offerings.

In this world of mortals, all are driven by the pursuit of fame and profit. Once entangled in schemes of gain and loss, how can one avoid the faults of greed and delusion? Thus, life departs in a single breath, and the soul is consigned to the Nine Dark Realms. Relying upon the causes of supreme goodness, may the suffering of the drowned and submerged be uplifted. With a heart full of sorrowful entreaty, I dedicate this merit to my departed ancestors.

Reciting the sacred scriptures from the Golden Casket, I look up to implore the True Sages. Honoring the exalted titles of the Lofty and Void, I bow to repay the roots of my lineage. I humbly pray that by the power of this Dao, the drowned and sunken may be broadly delivered; that measureless transgressions be extinguished, and the long night be illuminated; that the great pardon of Heaven be bestowed, universally benefiting all beings. May the myriad generations of my ancestors, from the most distant to the nearest, all attain the ascent to transcendence. May accumulated debts and layered grievances all be granted liberation and deliverance.

Furthermore, I pray that my household—young and old, kin and relations—may constantly partake in auspicious blessings and receive the sheltering shade of the Void and Nonexistence.

I, your servant, gaze toward Heaven and long for the Sages, overwhelmed with fervent devotion.

The Dao declares: The mysterious scriptures have now fully circulated. They may be transmitted to the world to broadly extend salvation and deliverance.

At that time, the assembled multitude, upon hearing this Dharma-condition, penetrated the Unconditioned. Together, they ascended to the fruition of the Dao. In the Fengdu prisons of the netherworld, countless sinful souls all attained meritorious transformation and were instantly liberated. The hosts of Heavenly Immortals rejoiced, paid reverence, and withdrew.

Here ends *The Wondrous Scripture of the Golden Casket and Jade Mirror: Pointers to the Mysteries of Cultivating the True*.
